problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

objective:
# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))) -> int:
    max_box_used: int = 0
    for i in range(1, N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS + 1):
        box_nr: int = item_box_assignments[i]
        if box_nr > max_box_used:
            max_box_used = box_nr
    return max_box_used

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)
constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def fit_items_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure items fit within the box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT
        assert positions[i].x >= 0
        assert positions[i].y >= 0

fit_items_in_boxes(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check for overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Calculate boundaries for item i
                xi_end: int = positions[i].x + items[i].width
                yi_end: int = positions[i].y + items[i].height
                # Calculate boundaries for item j
                xj_end: int = positions[j].x + items[j].width
                yj_end: int = positions[j].y + items[j].height
                # Assert that the rectangles do not overlap
                assert (
                    xi_end <= positions[j].x or
                    xj_end <= positions[i].x or
                    yi_end <= positions[j].y or
                    yj_end <= positions[i].y
                )

no_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_assignment_and_position(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Each item is assigned to exactly one box (already implied by domain of assignments)
        assert assignments[i] >= 1
        assert assignments[i] <= 20
        # Position values are within box boundaries
        assert positions[i].x >= 0
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert positions[i].y >= 0
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT

ensure_item_assignment_and_position(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- Objects ---


# Object type for an item with width and height
Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=100),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=100)
})

# Object type for the position (x, y) of an item within a box
Position = DSRecord({
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=100),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=100)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT: int = 100
BOX_WIDTH: int = 100
ITEMS: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item) = [{"width": 11, "height": 79}, {"width": 84, "height": 31}, {"width": 18, "height": 91}, {"width": 78, "height": 55}, {"width": 27, "height": 87}, {"width": 8, "height": 88}, {"width": 40, "height": 68}, {"width": 16, "height": 74}, {"width": 54, "height": 53}, {"width": 2, "height": 98}, {"width": 24, "height": 88}, {"width": 65, "height": 82}, {"width": 45, "height": 92}, {"width": 7, "height": 80}, {"width": 79, "height": 23}, {"width": 26, "height": 74}, {"width": 47, "height": 35}, {"width": 24, "height": 71}, {"width": 76, "height": 75}, {"width": 99, "height": 55}]
N_ITEMS: int = 20
nr_used_boxes: DSInt(lb=0, ub=20)
item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
x_y_positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
N_ITEMS : int = 20
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 20
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 20


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(item_box_assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))) -> int:
    max_box_used: int = 0

        box_nr: int = item_box_assignments[i]
        if box_nr > max_box_used:
            max_box_used = box_nr
    return max_box_used

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.

        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---

def prevent_item_overlap(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Calculate edges for item i
                i_right: int = positions[i].x + items[i].width
                i_bottom: int = positions[i].y + items[i].height
                # Calculate edges for item j
                j_right: int = positions[j].x + items[j].width
                j_bottom: int = positions[j].y + items[j].height
                # Assert that the rectangles do not overlap
                # Overlap occurs if both rectangles intersect in both x and y dimensions
                assert not (
                    positions[i].x < j_right and
                    i_right > positions[j].x and
                    positions[i].y < j_bottom and
                    i_bottom > positions[j].y
                )

prevent_item_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items to be placed in the box

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments : Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.
